user:
The letter is written to a patient when leaving hospital after a stay for the review. It should be prose and not contain bullet points.
Include summary of stay including, if applicable, key issues, interventions, procedures, and treatments.
Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

This is an example of discharge summary letter:
Dear ___,

You came into hospital because you were getting more short of breath and your ankles were swollen.

A heart scan, called an echocardiogram, showed that your heart was not pumping as well as it should.

We started you on water tablets called Furosemide. They will stop fluid collecting in your legs and lungs.

Please take 2 Furosemide tablets (2 x 40 mg = 80 mg) each morning and weigh yourself each morning.

If your weight drops by more than 2 kg over the week, reduce the dose to 1 tablet per day.

We have asked your GP practice to see you in about 2 weeks' time. They will take a blood test to check your kidney function.

We will see you in 6 weeks' time in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.

You will receive an appointment letter in the post.

Sincerely,
____

Dear ___,

You were admitted to the hospital on February 10, 2024, presenting with symptoms including cough, shortness of breath, hemoptysis, and fever. Upon arrival, your vital signs revealed a temperature of 38.5°C, a heart rate of 90 beats per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 92%. A chest X-ray indicated consolidation in the left lower lobe, suggestive of pneumonia. Initial laboratory tests showed elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) at 60 mg/L and white blood cell count at 12 x10^9/L.

Upon admission, you were diagnosed with lobar pneumonia of unspecified organism (J18.1). Empirical antibiotic therapy with Amoxicillin IV at a dose of 500 mg every eight hours was initiated, and symptomatic management with Paracetamol was provided as needed to control your fever and discomfort.

Throughout your stay, there was a notable improvement in your condition. By February 11, 2024, your temperature had decreased to 37.8°C, and your CRP levels had lowered to 50 mg/L. Your treatment regimen was adjusted, maintaining Amoxicillin IV at a reduced daily dosage of 250 mg and introducing Atorvastatin PO 20 mg nightly for concomitant management.

By February 12, 2024, further clinical improvement was observed. Your temperature returned to normal (37°C), and oxygen saturation increased to 96%. Laboratory tests showed a continued decline in CRP levels to 35 mg/L and a white blood cell count of 9 x10^9/L. Plans were made to transition you to oral antibiotics the following day.

On February 13, 2024, your condition continued to progress positively, with your temperature stabilizing at 36.5°C, and oxygen saturation rising to 98%. Your CRP level had decreased significantly to 20 mg/L, and your white blood cell count normalized to 7 x10^9/L. Consequently, Amoxicillin was administered orally at 250 mg daily.

On February 14, 2024, you were assessed to have improved significantly and deemed medically fit for discharge. You were provided with instructions to continue oral antibiotics for an additional five days. Arrangements have been made for you to follow up in the outpatient clinic in two weeks to monitor your recovery and ensure no recurrence of symptoms.

We thank you for your cooperation during your hospital stay and wish you a continued and smooth recovery. Should you experience any new symptoms or concerns, we encourage you to reach out to your healthcare provider promptly.

Sincerely,

___
